slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.content:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  1. Understand the image degradation model
  2. Characterize point spread functions (PSF)
  3. Apply inverse and Wiener filtering
  4. Implement iterative restoration methods
  5. Evaluate restoration quality using metrics

slides.title: Degradation Model
slides.content: Understanding how images become degraded

slides.title: Image Degradation Model
slides.content:
$$g(x,y) = h(x,y) * f(x,y) + n(x,y)$$

g = degraded image, h = PSF, f = original, n = noise

slides.title: Noise Models
slides.content: Common noise distributions: Gaussian, Poisson, salt & pepper

slides.title: Point Spread Function (PSF)
slides.content:
PSF: The impulse response of the imaging system - how a point source is blurred.

  • Motion blur: Linear PSF in direction of motion
  • Out-of-focus: Circular (pillbox) PSF
  • Atmospheric: Gaussian-like PSF

knowledgeCheck.question: Why is knowing the PSF important for image restoration?
knowledgeCheck.answer: The PSF describes exactly how the image was blurred. Restoration algorithms use this knowledge to reverse (deconvolve) the blurring process.

slides.title: Restoration Methods
slides.content: Recovering the original image

slides.title: Spatial Filtering for Restoration
slides.content: Simple spatial filters can reduce some types of degradation

slides.title: Frequency Domain Restoration
slides.content:
Inverse Filter:

$$\hat{F}(u,v) = \frac{G(u,v)}{H(u,v)}$$

Problem: Amplifies noise where H(u,v) is small!

slides.title: Wiener Filter
slides.content:
Wiener Filter:

$$\hat{F}(u,v) = \frac{H^*(u,v)}{|H(u,v)|^2 + \frac{S_n}{S_f}} \cdot G(u,v)$$

Balances deconvolution against noise amplification

knowledgeCheck.question: What advantage does the Wiener filter have over simple inverse filtering?
knowledgeCheck.answer: It incorporates noise statistics to avoid amplifying noise in frequency regions where the signal-to-noise ratio is low.

slides.title: Motion Blur Restoration
slides.content: Restoring images degraded by camera or object motion

slides.title: Iterative Methods
slides.content: Richardson-Lucy and other iterative approaches

slides.title: Richardson-Lucy Algorithm
slides.content:
Richardson-Lucy: Iterative ML estimation for Poisson noise.

$$f^{(k+1)} = f^{(k)} \cdot \left( h(-x,-y) * \frac{g}{h * f^{(k)}} \right)$$

Converges to maximum likelihood solution; good for astronomical images.

slides.title: Restoration Comparison
slides.content: Comparing different restoration methods on the same degraded image

slides.title: Quality Metrics
slides.content:
PSNR

$$PSNR = 10\log_{10}\frac{MAX^2}{MSE}$$

SSIM

Structural similarity considering luminance, contrast, structure

slides.title: Summary
slides.content: Key Takeaways

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.content:
1. Degradation model: g = h*f + n (blur + noise)
  2. PSF: Characterizes the blur - motion, defocus, atmospheric
  3. Inverse filter: Simple but amplifies noise
  4. Wiener filter: Optimal linear filter balancing deconvolution and noise
  5. Richardson-Lucy: Iterative method for Poisson noise
  6. Quality metrics: PSNR and SSIM for objective evaluation
